Introduction
Overview
The enemies are at the gates brothers! Mankind is assailed on all sides. Go, tell them that they shall have no satisfaction while we still stand. Those that seek to destroy us, both from without and from within, shall rue the day that they first sought our downfall, those that have sought to sow the wind, shall now reap the whirlwind.
GM NPC Player Character Non-Player Character Character Malleus~Deum is a fantasy pen and paper, tabletop, role-playing game (TTRPG). In Malleus Deum one player assumes the role of Game Master or GM and plays the part of a narrator in a collaborative story. Other players adopt the role of individual people within the story, called Player Characters. All the other characters, and any monsters within the story are controlled by the GM and are referred to as Non-Player Characters or NPCs. We use the term Character to denote both player characters and non-player characters.
CheckDifficulty CheckDC Each player character is described by a Character Sheet. Any narrative decisions of moment within the game are made by Making Checks which involves rolling dice. The details of how this all fits together, how to create a character, how to make checks, and more is covered in the next few chapters.
Character Creation ch:character-creation
Character Overview
Character Player Characters are described by:
An Archetype and a Level. The Archetype describes the characters race and their profession. The Level describes how advanced, how powerful, the character is.
Primary Abilities A set of five Primary Abilities: Strength, Endurance, Agility, Speed, and Perception.
Four or more Defensive Abilities: Armour, Dodge, Block and Parry.
Two Hit Point stats: Stamina and Health.
Three Dice Pool stats: Mettle, Magic, and Luck.
A set of Aspects. Aspects are statements that describe some facet of the characters personality, relationships, or philosophy e.g: Silent Outcast, Naive Appeaser, Dipsomaniac, Declared vengeance against Elogh King of the Goblins. Aspects are tied to game mechanics and have real consequences in the game,
A range of other Abilities, drawn from four groups General, Lore, Martial and Magic, Sword Strike, Arcane Lore, Pick Locks, and
Optionally, a description of the character, a back-story for the character, and any tertiary statistics the player might want to include: Height, Weight, Age, Hair Colour and so on.
The characters abilities and aspects allow players to make checks to see whether their characters can successfully perform certain actions within the game. Checks are described further in Sectionsec:checks on pagesec:checks. Steps to create a character can be found in the archetype document for the archetype you wish to play.
Young Dourli, Dwarven Shield Guard
For examples sake, in this book, we shall illustrate game mechanics using three PCs Dourli, intrepid dwarven warrior; Rozlyn, shadowy cutpurse; and Mophissius, sometime dabbler in the dark arts.
Archetypes
Archetype Each character has an archetype. An Archetype is a combination of a race and a class, for example a character might choose to be a Dwarven Shield Warrior or a Halfling Rover. Archetypes define which abilities a character may have or learn and how hard it is for them to acquire that ability.
Archetypes are indivisible because it makes them more modular and allows us to balance one archetype without effecting existing archetypes.
Level
Level Each character has a level which represents how much experience the characters has. The character's level usually starts at one and increases when the GM decides that it is appropriate. There are no experience points in this game. As a rule of thumb characters should gain levels at the end of a story arc or when the players have accomplished something noteworthy in the game.
Primary Abilities
All characters share a set of Primary Abilities that describe the characters physical capabilities. These provide a bonus to certain checks and may be prerequisites for other abilities. In Malleus Deum primary attributes are treated like all other abilities, see Sectionsec:primary_abilities on pagesec:primary_abilities.
Strengthphysical power Endurancetoughness, fitness and physical robustness Agilitynimbleness and fine motor control Speedswiftness and fleetness of movement Perceptioninsight and ability to notice things
Defensive Abilities Defence Check
Defensive abilities represent how difficult a character is to hit. When an NPC tries to hit a PC in combat the player makes a defensive ability check against the difficulty of the attack. The four most common defensive abilities that are available to all characters are Armour, Dodge, Parry and Block, though there are others. We use the term Defence Check Defensive Checks to refer to these ability checks irrespective of what underlying defensive ability the player choose to make the check.
Armour
Defensivesee Armour
The character takes the brunt of the attack on their armour, hoping that it will protect them. The bonus for this check is determined by the armour the character is wearing. A character may be harder to hit because they are wearing armour or carrying a shield.
Dodge
Defensivesee Dodge
The character uses the dodge ability to attempt to leap out of the way of the attack, see pageability:dodge.
Block
Defensivesee Block
The character blocks the attack using a shield or buckler using the Shield Block skill, see pageability:block.
Parry
Defensivesee Parry
The character attempts to stop the attack by parrying with their weapon using the Parry skill (if the weapon can be used to parry). Different weapon classes have their own parry abilities, see Staff Parry on pageability:staff.parry. and Sword Parry on pageability:sword.parry.
Dice Pool Statistics
Characters have three dice pool statistics: Mettle, Magic and Luck. Dice pools consist of a number of six sided dice. Players start the game with full dice pools. During the game they may lose dice from those pools by making dice pool checks, and they may return dice to their pools using various means including by resting. We describe how to use dice pools to make checks in Sectionsec:dice-pool on pagesec:dice-pool.
Mettle
Poolssee Mettle This dice pool measures the characters strength of character, their spirits and will-power, their mental well-being, morale, fear, shock, sanity and determination.
Magic
Poolssee Magic
Casting magic uses a dice pool and many special rules described in Sectionch:magic on pagech:magic.
Not all characters are able to cast spells, but all characters have a magic pool. This pool represents their animus, their spark of life, and can be use to resist spells.
Luck
Poolssee Luck
Luck Pool Characters have a Luck Pool that represents the players manifest destiny, their luck.
Hit Points
A characters physical well-being is represented by two sets of statistics: Stamina and Health, collectively called their Hit Points.
Stamina
Staminasee Hit Points
Stamina is the characters freshness, their energy, their vigour, and their ability to shrug off minor wounds, bruising, scratches, glancing blows, near misses and the like. Damage to stamina leaves the character breathless, a little stunned, bruised and battered but not physically too badly hurt. As the character's Stamina decreases their ability to fend off serious damage from attackers decreases and the danger of getting really physically hurt increases. Stamina heals quickly.
Health
HealingHealth
represents the characters brawn, their physical capacity to take damage. Damage to health reprensts open lacerations, deep bruising, sprained joints. Wounds that take time to heal, so it takes time to restore health. The character gains Health back slowly, at their Rest Rate when they Sleep.
Health Zero Health Characters can take damage to either of these stats as the result of an in-game event. For example, when a character takes damage during combat they will usually take it from their Stamina first and then their Health. Other damage, such as falling damage, applies directly to Health irrespective of the current Stamina.
Dourli, our amiable dwarven friend has somehow managed to find himself in a brawl with some of the towns thugs. He stabs one of the thugs for 4 damage. The thug has only 3 Stamina remaining so his Stamina is reduced to 0, his Health is reduced by 1. The thug is bloodied and has to make a morale check. He rolls poorly and flees the fight.
Both of Stamina and Health have a minimum value of zero, they cannot be negative numbers. A character with zero Stamina gains the Bloodied condition. A character with zero Health is Down, see pagesec:conditions for more information on conditions. Characters who are down are effectively too hurt and too weak to defend themselves or do too much and are in danger of dying, see Sectionsec:death on pagesec:death of the GMG. See Sectionsec:healing on pagesec:healing for information on Healing.
Other Abilities Abilities
Abilities In addition to primary and defensive abilities, each character has a range of other Abilities represent learned skills which allow them to perform actions within the game.
A character's initial abilities are determined by their archetype. The characters archetype assigns a number of abilities for the player to choose from. Abilities are discussed further in Chapterch:abilities on pagech:abilities. Characters gain abilities when they gain levels.
Abilities are divided using tags into a number of categorizes. For example, the Axe Strike ability is tagged Weapon, Heavy, Martial, Axe. This means that if the character gains a martial ability when they go up a level they may take the Axe Strike ability or any of the other martial abilities of the given rank. If the character gains an axe ability they may only choose from the abilities tagged with axe. In order to take an ability the abilities prerequisites must be met.
Ability Rank Rank - Ability Abilities have ranks and the higher the ability rank the easier it is for the character to succeed at those ability checks. Ability ranks are written after the ability. So, for example, we might say that Dourli has Axe Cleave 3, which means that he has Axe Cleave at rank 3.
Ability[Templates] Template - Ability Some abilities may be templated. In this case the template will follow the ability name and be written in square brackets, History[Westreich] 2. The template indicates that the knowledge is narrower than the ability name alone suggests. The GM can choose whatever template values they like for templated abilities.
Aspects
Aspects are descriptions about a characters personality, their philosophy or their relationships. Aspects tie those descriptions to game mechanics and allow checks to be made against them. Aspects are defined in detail in chapter Chapterch:aspects on pagech:aspects. We describe the process by which aspects are assigned to new characters in Sectionch:character-creation on character creation.
Background
Players may create a background or back-story for their character. At least some of the players background should be fleshed out at character creation time. The background helps to tie characters to one another and to give them a purpose and a feeling for how they fit in the world. This is best done collaboratively with the GM and possibly with the other players as well.
Leveling Upsec:leveling_up
At some point in the game the GM will notify the characters that they have leveled up. The archetype document has a table at the back of the changes availble to the character for their new level.
Changes are of the following types.
New LevelThe player should modify the level for their character on the character sheet. Increased Stamina or HealthThe player increases the amount of the relevant hit points on their character sheet. Gain AbilityAbilityGainingGaining an Ability The character may gain a completely new ability. The character must be able to learn the ability, and the character must have mastered any prerequisites. Ability PromotionAbilityPromotionsPromoting an AbilityAn ability promotion allows the character to increase the rank of an already mastered ability by one.
Checks
Making Checks sec:checks
Check In this chapter we describe Checks, the core mechanic of the game. Checks are used to determine whether a character can do things, like climbing a wall, closing a protective circle, blocking an attack against them, casting a spell, or jumping a horse over a fence. In order for a players character to perform a challenging action they must make a Check which involves rolling some dice, possibly adding a modifier and determining whether the total of the roll and modifier is greater than or equal to some difficulty, if so the check succeeds, otherwise it fails.
There are two main varieties of check: Standard 2d12 Checks, and d6 Dice Pool Checks. These two checks use a different set of dice and have different rules.
Standard Checks
Standard Check CheckStandard Standard Checks are the simplest and most common check. In order to make a Standard Check (Std Check) the player rolls 2d12, adds any relevant bonus for proficiency in the skill being used to the result. The check succeeds if the total dice result rolled is greater than or equal to the task's difficulty. The GM determines the Difficulty (DC) and any modifiers. The modifiers may be different for different characters.
Std Check: 2d12 + Bonus DC - Modifiers ... the Bonus is usually the Ability Rank
Modifier Bonus CheckModifiers CheckBonus The value on the left in the equation above is calculated by the player making the check, the value on the right is calculated by the GM. Note that the modifier is subtracted from the DC. That means that modifiers for the players that are good are always positive, modifiers that are bad for the players are negative. This distinction becomes important for dice pool checks which have an overcharge value.
CheckDDC The DC for the check is determined by GM fiat based on their interpretation of the difficulty of the task, the current environment and any other factors that might apply. Some abilities have a Default Difficulty, or DDC this number represents a non-binding suggestion to the GM for a DC for a typical check for this ability.
Doubles Are Special
Boon Bane Standard CheckBoon Standard CheckBane When rolling Std Checks there are a few special results. Doubles rolled on Std Checks trigger unusual effects. Double odds are bad and trigger a Bane, double evens are good, granting a Boon to the character.
Double 1s
Is a Critical FailureCritical Failure. It always automatically fails. In addition the character receives a significant bane.
Other Double Odds
If the player rolls any other odd double result then their character receives a bane.
Double 12s
Is a Critical SuccessCritical Success which is always an automatic success. In addition the character receives a significant boon.
Other Double Evens
If the player rolls any other even double result then their character receives a boon.
Boons and Banes
Boons
Boon Whether the check succeeds or not, through skill or luck, the character has gained some advantage. When the character gains a boon the GM may describe the boon or may allow the player to call the result, describing the result of the check to the rest of the table. The player is allowed to add some minor advantageous secondary effect to the result. For example, the opponent could be pushed back, drop the scroll they are carrying, or be forced to make a morale check. As always the GM is the final arbiter of whether a players call is reasonable and he may temper the results of the success, as he chooses.
Banes
Bane Something has gone wrong. The GM should describe some additional bad outcome for the check, or roll on one of the failure tables for inspiration. For example, the character may have struck with the flat of the blade (requiring the weapon to make a save), they may have lost their footing, left themselves open to attack or dropped some item they were carrying. In other words, some adverse affect applies. The GM should decide on an appropriate bane for the character, or roll on one of the blunder tables for inspiration.
Dourli has to make a quick getaway from a burning stable surrounded by a crossbow wielding gang. The one horse inside the stable is panicking because of the fire.
Dourli attempts to mount the horse and ride to freedom. Dourli doesn't have Horsemanship or Animal Husbandry but he does have a fairly good Strength. So Dourli attempts to control the horse using a Strength Ability Check. The GM decides that the task has a difficulty of 14, so Dourli must roll a 14 or more in order to get the horse under control. Dourli has a Strength 2, he has the Strength ability at rank 2, and so he gets a bonus to his role of +2. Dourli rolls a pair of fives on his 2d12, for a total of 10 and adds his Strength Rank of 2 to get 12 which isn't enough to make the 14 required to control the horse. In addition, because he rolled double odds he suffers a bane. The GM declares that the horse bolts, smashing through the burning stable doors and running into the night.
Advanage and Disadvantage
Advantage Disadvantage When making a standard check with advantage the player rolls three d12s and chooses the highet two results. When making a standard check with disadvantage the player rolls three dice and chooses the lowest two.
Dichotomy of Std Checks, Difficulty vs Bonuses
We can easily convert back and forth between a Std Check DC and a Std Check Bonus. The average value of 2d12 is 13. To convert from a DC to a Std Check Bonus we subtract the DC from 13. To convert back from a Std Check Bonus to a DC just add 13. Alternatively, use the Tabletable:phb-std-check-dc-to-bonus on pagetable:phb-std-check-dc-to-bonus. In this way the GM can quickly change who rolls the die for a check. This may be handy when characters are performing opposed rolls against other player characters. Or if the GM wants to roll against a characters ability as a DC instead of having the character roll aginst the DC they provide. It is the GM's prerogative who rolls for a check.
{% include "docs/tables/std_check_dc_to_bonus.xml" %}
Some Exceptions
Abilities tagged Untrained or Primary can be used without training. In these cases the lowest ability rank is used. Abilities tagged Inaccurate do not add their rank to their checks.
Dice Pool Checksec:dice-pool
Dice Pool Check CheckDice Pool Dice pools represent some finite resource that will run out if overused, for player characters these are Magic, Mettle and Luck, but monsters, magic items, and other things can have dice pools as well. When the player has to make a dice pool check they choose one or more d6s from their dice pool and roll them to try and get a result greater than or equal to a given difficulty or DC. Some dice pool checks will also have an overcharge value (usually relative to the DC, DC+6). If the result is greater than or equal to the over charge then the check succeeds however a bane occurs.
Dice Pool Check: DC - Modifiers Dice Result Over-Charge
Dice Pool CheckExhaustion CheckDice Pool Exhaustion Doubles have no special effect in Dice Pool Checks. However, when a dice rolls low, that dice is said to be Exhausted. For most dice pool checks, and unless otherwise stated, dice in a dice pool are exhausted when they roll a two or less. Though exhaustion for magic dice pools is more complicated, and magic dice may be exhausted at even higher values depending on the context of the casting, see the rules of magic for more information.
The PC dice pools: Magic, Mettle and Luck dice are restored to the pool by resting or through the use of special abilities. For other dice pools, some magic item magic pools, exhausted dice can never be replaced, others dice pools will have their own replacement schedule.
The number of dice in a characters dice pools are defined by their archetype, level and abilities. For character dice pools like Luck, Magic and Mettle the dice pools will have a rest rate which allows the player to return dice to his dice pool over time or when certain events occur. For magical items and other dice pool checks the loss might be permanent. Exhaustion only applies to Dice Pool Checks, not Std Checks.
Dice Pool CheckShared Dice Pools Shared Dice Pool Some checks will allow the use of a Shared Pool of Dice. In this case the dice to be used are selected from all the pools before the check. Then all the selected dice are rolled simultaneously but are kept separate. The check succeeds or fails based on the sum of all the dice rolled. Dice are exhausted from the pool from whence the die came. Characters do not decide which pools to exhaust dice from.
Dice Pool CheckEmpty Empty Dice Pool When a dice pool is empty, it has had all its dice exhausted, any further checks made against that pool automatically fail.
Dice Pool CheckModifiers Modifier to a Dice Pool Check Like a Std Check, a Dice Pool Check can have modifiers. These modifiers effect the DC for the check and are suggestions for the GM. For example a +1 DC modifier reduces a dice pools checks difficulty by one, making the check easier, but does not effect the checks overcharge. A -1 DC modifier makes the check harder and does not effect the checks overcharge.
Types of Check
There are many different types of Check. When choosing which one to use the rule of thumb is use the check most specific ability to the task at hand. The less relevant an ability is to a task the harder the DC should be to perform that task.
Ability Checks
Ability Checks are any checks against an ability. For example attack rolls are a type of ability check using an appropriate weapon abiliy, as are spell casting checks using the appropriate magic ability. For these checks the dice used, the modifier and a suggested default difficulty are provided in the ability description. To Hit Check ChecksTo Hit
{% include "docs/tables/std_check_difficulties.xml" %}
Dourli attempts to strike a thug with his axe using the Axe Strike ability which he has at Rank 1. He rolls 2d12+1 and the difficulty is the thugs defence DC. The +1 bonus is provided by his rank with the Axe Strike ability.
Primary Ability Checks
ChecksAbility Ability Check Primary Ability Check Primary Ability Checks are a special type of ability check, that are made using one of the characters primary abilities, when no more specific check applies, a character might check their agility when trying to catch a falling object as there is no catch ability. To check whether a character can make it to shore from a sinking ship should be made using the swim ability and not the endurance primary ability.
These checks work the same as other ability checks, the character rolls a Std Check which is modified by the characters Primary Ability Rank and the result is compared against a DC chosen by the GM as they see fit. For inspiration see Tabletable:std-check-difficulties on pagetable:std-check-difficulties for a list of suggested difficulties.
Dourli tries to shift a large wine barrel that is sitting on a trap door in a cellar. The GM declares that in order to do so Dourli must make a Strength Check with a difficulty of 12. The player rolls a 4 and a 5 on their 2d12. Dourli has Strength 2, and so gets a bonus of +2 for a total of 11. Dourli fails to move the wine barrel. If he had a Strength 3 he would have succeeded.
{% include "docs/tables/ability_modifiers.xml" %}
Aspect Checks
Aspect checks are standard checks against an aspects difficulty. They are discussed further in Chapterch:aspects on pagech:aspects.
Hidden or Passive Ability Checks
ChecksPassive ChecksHidden Passive Check Hidden Check Passive Perception Check When players should not know that a check is being made the GM can secretly make those checks for them, and the player is a passive participant. We call this a passive check. A good example of this is a passive perception check. In order to make a passive perception check, the GM rolls a Std Check and adds the characters perception rank for the character and compares it with the nominated DC.
Opposed Checks
CheckOpposed Opposed Check TiesOpposed Check In an Opposed Check instead of checking against a DC the player character checks against their opponents check result for the same ability. In the case of ties between players the result is a success with a bane.
Opposed Ability Check
Std2d12 + Mod. > Std2d12 + Opponents Mod.
Dourli wants to convince the Mage Guilds Presidium that Mophissius's Maester has been involved in nefarious dealings. Mophissius's wants to stop him. Dourli tries to negotiate with the Presidium to convince them. In this context Negotiate is an Opposed Ability Check. The players role-play the presentation of their characters arguments and evidence and the GM then, optionally, awards bonuses to the check based on the characters role-playing. Finally, both Dourli and Mophissius roll and add their negotiate bonus and any additional contextual bonus the GM awarded. Whoevers modified roll is higher wins. Ties draw.
When making an opposed ability check against an NPC the GM can state a difficulty for the player to beat, converting the opposed ability check into a normal ability check.
Hidden Opposed Checks CheckOpposed, Hidden Hidden Opposed Check
A Hidden Opposed Check is an Opposed Ability Check where the GM makes the opposing check in secret. This means that the players can have some idea about how likely they are to have succeeded after the check but will not be certain of their success or failure.
Consider the intrepid Dourli playing cards in an ale house. He is trying to spread a rumour that an opposing gang of thieves is responsible for his latest heist. The GM could choose to play this as a hidden opposed Deceive check or just a straight check against a stated DC. The former means that Dourli cannot be sure of his result, unless he rolls a critical, while the latter is a little simpler and faster.
Morale Checks
Morale Check Break CheckMorale Check ChecksMorale ChecksBreak see Morale Check Morale Checks occur when characters have to face their fears. This process is described further in Sectionsec:mettle-checks on pagesec:mettle-checks.
Encumbrance Checks (Optional)
ChecksEncumbrance Encumbrance Check Encumbrance is an optional rule. When the characters are doing something where the weight of their pack could be problematic then the GM can make the player roll against encumbrance. This check is discussed further in Sectionsec:encumbrance on pagesec:encumbrance.
Generic Checks
Generic checks are a catch-all check for when nothing else applies. The player rolls a Std Check against a difficulty chosen by the GM.
Other Check Details
Rounding
Rounding CheckRounding Some rules require numeric values to be halved, quartered and so on. For example a bane on a combat roll halves the damage done, and falling damage can do a quarter of your hit points damage. What do we do decide what half of an odd number is? The rule is: Always round down. So half of 7 is 3, and a quarter of 7 is 1.
Rerolls
AbilitiesRerolls Rerolls The most important rule for rerolls is that no check can be rerolled more than once for any reason. Secondly, a reroll is just that. The Character cannot choose to perform a different action, they are already committed to performing the original action, they are just able to reroll the check. If the player rerolls the check they must take the result from the second roll. When making a reroll the player must reroll the same number of dice they used in the original check - they cannot choose to add or remove dice from the check. All checks may be rerolled unless the ability states otherwise. When a dice pool check is rerolled, exhausted dice are lost from the reroll but not from the original roll.
How often can you Check?
AbilitiesCheck Once In the usual course of play each character can perform a check once - twice if a reroll is used. For example, Dourli might try opening a box quickly by picking locks. If Dourli fails he might check to open the box with his axe but he can't try picking the lock again. The GM may consider that Dourli has used all the time available in his attempt to pick the lock and so no other characters may attempt to do so, or that there is further time available and someone else can try and pick the lock.
The GM should use their commonsense to determine what constitutes a new check, an attempt to quickly open a lock is one check. However Dourli may be able to make multiple checks to see if he can shoot a lever on the other side of a room as each shot is it's own new and unique check.
AbilitiesTaking Time Taking Time Many tasks can be automatically completed given enough time. For example, for a mundane lock the GM might rule that Dourli automatically unlocks the box if he spends a few hours tinkering with it. This process is called Taking Time.
When to Check?
As a GM when should you require that your players make a check? Make sure that you only require players to check when: the outcome is uncertain and failure makes the game more interesting. Many tasks are easy enough that they can be completed automatically. In this case no check is required to perform the action. Harder variants of the task might require a check though. For example, opening a door might be considered an easy task that automatically succeeds, while opening a door quietly might require a check. Similarly breaking down a door might require a check to perform quickly but can be done automatically given enough time and given that one of the characters has an axe.
Party/Group Checks
Group Checks Party Checks ChecksGroup ChecksParty Sometimes checks have to be made by the party. In this section we discuss the different party checks.
Everyone Checks
Everyone Checks ChecksEveryone Sometimes everyone in a group has to make a check. For example, if the party is attacked using poisonous gas everyone in the party has to save. When Everyone Checks, each group member makes a separate check independent of the rest of the group and each individual suffers any repercussions separately if they fail.
Delegate Checks
Delegate Checks ChecksDelegate In a delegate check a player character is delegated by the GM to make a check on behalf of the whole group. If that check fails the party fails the check. The GM may choose the delegate at random or at their own discretion. Some examples of Delegate Checks are Initiative, Stealth, Perception, Ambush and Surprise rolls. But more on these later.
Tags, Conditions, and Aspects ch:aspects
Tags
Tag A Tag is a label or signifier attached to something in the world. A cellar might be dark and musty, or a monsters attack might be necrotic Damage Type. If the GM describes a cellar as being dark then we say it is tagged dark, a dwarven character is tagged dwarf. Tags form a bridge between the narrative game and the game rules.
Various rules apply only when certain tags are in play. Other events apply new tags to characters, objects and scenarios in the game. Characters may use tags to gain an advantage in a check. Tags may also be prerequisites for using abilities, describe weapon damage types, properties that effect magic use, monster classes
Dourli hides from a local gang of thugs in a cellar. The GM describes the cellar as dark and dank and storing old barrels. The thugs enter the cellar and look around. Dourli invokes the dark tag of the cellar saying ``They'll have trouble seeing me in the dark''. The GM agrees and reduces the difficulty of Dourli's Sneak check.
Conditions sec:conditions
Condition A Condition is a tag with explicit in-game rules attached to it. All conditions are tags, but not all tags are conditions. What follows is a list of some common conditions.
Aflame
Aflame Condition ConditionsAflame The character is on fire. They must attempt to put out the fire or make a Morale Check each round to resist doing so.
Alert
Alert Condition ConditionsAlert condition:alert The character is alert for danger. They are less likely to be surprised. They gain +3 to Awareness checks. It is difficult to stay alert for long periods of time. PCs cannot claim to be alert for hours on end. Something has to happen to alert them. For example, guards are typically not alert, infiltrators typically are alert. If a group is makes a lot of noise, due to combat, then other groups nearby will become alert.
Aware
Aware Condition ConditionsAware See the description of Aware in the Surprise section on pagesec:aware. If a character is not Aware they are Unaware.
Blind
Blind Condition ConditionsBlind The character cannot see. Ambush, Surprise, Initiative, Attack Roles, Dodge, Parry and Block receive a -6 modifier against all opponents.
Bloodied
Bloodied Condition ConditionsBloodied The character has suffered damage to their Health. When a character first suffers health damage in a fight they must make a morale check.
Broken
condition:broken Broken Condition ConditionsBroken The character has lost the will to fight and must withdraw from battle. On their turn they may attack but must move away from the enemy if they can. This condition occurs after a character has failed two morale checks in combat.
Checked
condition:checked Checked Condition ConditionsChecked The character has lost momentum in a fight. The character must make an additional Morale Check to charge or pursue. This condition occurs after the character has failed a single morale check in combat.
Dazed
Dazed Condition ConditionsDazed The character receives a -3 modifer to all Checks. This often occurs when the character has suffered a nasty injury and are suffering a great deal of pain Endurance check DDC 12 ends the condition.
Drunk
Drunk Condition ConditionsDrunk The character has had too much alcohol to drink. They make Agility and Perception checks at -3 and they make Luck checks at +3.
Distracted
Distracted Condition ConditionsDistracted Something has caught the characters attention and they are not paying attention to their surrounds. They make Ambush, Surprise, Perception Checks at -3.
Deaf
Deaf Condition ConditionsDeaf The character cannot hear. They make checks Ambush, Surprise, Perception Checks at -3 and have some trouble communicating with others, use Language saves to determine success.
Down
Down Condition ConditionsDown The character is very badly hurt, semi-conscious and is only capable of making a single minor action in their turn. Characters who are Down also have the Near-Death condition and usually have the Prone condition as well.
Enraged
Enraged Condition ConditionsEnraged The character is wild with rage. They can't flee or retreat. Mettle check DDC 3 to save.
Exhausted

Flanked

Immune[]
Immune[] Condition ConditionsImmune[] The character takes no damage if they are immune to that type of damage. For example, if a character is Immune[Fire] and they take 6 points of damage tagged with Fire then they take no damage.
Inaccurate

ConditionSave Ends Save Ends At some point conditions may go away. There may be a number of circumstances listed when the condition is applied as to when the condition ends. One such way is when the character makes a save. This is called Save Ends, and it will usually be stated in terms of what ability to use and supply a default DC. For example text might say: If the character has a fishing net dropped on them they are Prone Agility ends with a DDC of 12. Saves are made at the end of the characters turn and, if they have multiple saves to make, in any order the character wishes.
Aspects
Role-playing is shared story-telling. Conflict and struggle are central to a good story. Aspects are the mechanic that we use to represent facets of the characters personality that can be used to create interesting, non-physical, internal or inter-personal conflict and character development within the game.
Aspect Aspects are special tags that describe some part of a characters personality, their system of beliefs, or their philosophy of life. Each aspect has a difficulty and the player can be forced to make checks against that difficulty or be compelled to behave in accordance with the aspect. The higher the difficulty the harder it is for the character to resist the aspect. For example Dourli might have the following aspects: Gold is my Lodestone 10, and My Word as a Dwarf 13.
There are many types of aspects. They fall loosely into the following categories:
Personality Aspects
describe some part of a characters personality or demeanour, their flaws and foibles, their short-comings, their weaknesses and sometimes their strengths, Mama's Boy, As Exciting as Cold Oatmeal, Plagued by Self-Doubt.
Philosophy Aspects
encode a character's beliefs and their moral compass: Defender of the Downtrodden, Man of the Book, Death before Dishonour.
Relationship Aspects
Relationship aspects can be used to describe a close bond between the character and an individual, a magic item, their god, a small group or even a large population. In the last case it comes in the form of fame, or infamy, with aspects like The Heroes of Izenholme, Chosen of the Elvin Council, Beholden to the Black Hand, or The Scourge of the Serpent People.
Discuss the role playing milieu with the GM. Get a feel for the colour of the world and the NPCs and organizations within it. Choose an aspect with the GM that ties your character to one of these NPCs or organizatio, or one of the player characters. Then choose a Personality or Philosophy aspect for your character.
Insanity, Curses, Diseases, and other effects
other in game conditions can be represented by aspects such as insanity, and various diseases. Players need not worry themselves over these during character creation.
Choosing Good Aspects
Aspects are used to drive conflict in the game. If the character is a Problem Gambler have the party visiting gambling dens so the character has to suffer an internal struggle not to gamble and have some thugs lean on the character to pay back his debts.
Good aspects are evocative of the characters personality, their belief system or their social status. They should not describe parts of the game already covered by existing game mechanics. For example, Greatest Swordsman Ever is not a good aspect - it interferes with the game rules on combat. Thinks He's the Greatest Swordsman Ever is much better because it establishes the character as a braggadocio. Remember that the Aspects should be chosen to create conflict and problems for the characters to overcome. If an Aspect does not cause the character to overcome difficulties or make interesting decisions it is not a good aspect. As a general rule good aspects are phrases that when applied require action from the character. Additionally they should be neither too specific nor too general. For good example aspects see the FATE RPG or Figurefigure:random-aspect-table on pagetable:{{ doc_name }}-random-aspects.
{% include "docs/tables/random_aspect_table.xml" %}
Aspect Creation
Creating Aspects Aspect Creation =9+d6 After an aspect is chosen the starting difficulty of that aspect must be determined. The difficulty of an Aspect always lies in the range 10 to 15 inclusive. Aspects acquired during character creation have an initial difficulty of $9 + 1d6$. Aspects whose difficulty falls below six are said to be diminished and no longer apply to the character. The aspect must be removed from the character sheet or demoted to a tag.
Compelling and Resisting Aspects
Compelling an Aspect AspectCompel Any player, including the GM, may attempt to Compel any characters aspect at any time, this includes a players own PC. Compelling aspects involves suggesting to a player that their character should follow a course of action in keeping with one of their aspects. The player who controls the character may then choose to accept or resist the compel.
If the player accepts a compel for an aspect then they should have their character behave in accordance with that aspect.
Resisting an Aspect AspectResist Alternatively, players may have their characters try to resist the compel as follows:
Roll an unmodified 2d12 if the result is less than the aspects difficulty the character is compelled.
If the check fails, increase the aspects difficulty by one.
If the check succeeds, decrease the aspects difficulty by one.
If a bane is rolled, increase the aspects difficulty by one.
If a boon is rolled, decrease the aspects difficulty by one.
If the player compelled themselves then decrease the aspects difficulty by one.
If the aspects difficulty is less than ten, then it becomes ten.
If the aspects difficulty is greater than fifteen, then it becomes fifteen.
Dourli hears that someone has offered 20gp for information about one of Dourli's colleagues. The GM might decide to try to compel Dourli as he has an aspect Gold is my Lodestone. The player then decides whether he will accept the compel and provide the information about his associate or resist the compel somehow.
He decides to resist. So he has to check against the difficulty of that aspect, which is currently 11. He rolls 2d12 (as aspect checks are standard checks) and rolls a total of 8. He fails as his dice result, 8, is lower than the aspects difficulty, 11 So now Dourli has to provide the information about his associate in order to garner his well earned gold. In addition, because he failed the aspect check he increases the difficulty of the aspect by one, to 12.
Dourli now decides that he cannot, just hand over the information about his associate, like a despicable cad, and instead resolves to try and give them bogus information. This action satisfies the compel as, if he succeeds, he still gets his gold.
A player may compel their own aspect in order to try to reduce the aspects difficulty, provided the GM agrees to the compel. When a player compels one of their own characters aspects they roll the check as normal. If they fail the aspect binds the character. If they succeed the check the aspect does not apply and the character must now reduce the difficulty of that aspect by one.
Aspect Difficulty and Lifetime
Aspects need not last the lifetime of the character. There are a limited number of aspects a character may have at any one time. Characters grow and over time the beliefs that shape them change and aspects they once described them may no longer apply. For example, a character might hold certain beliefs very strongly and, overtime, the strengths of those beliefs may wane. After some period, the character may become disenchanted with their former philosophy and move on. Perhaps they grow and realize the error of their ways, or maybe they continue to believe but their passion for the idea has gone.
Alternatively, the GM may at any time declare that a character loses an existing aspect, gains a new one, or he may reword an existing aspect. The GM should take care when doing this to keep the players vision of their character intact. You should consider modifying the characters aspects for one of the following reasons:
Manageability: if the character has too many aspects consider removing some, preferably starting with those with the lowest difficulties.
To satisfy the narrative imperative: if adding the aspect to the character would drive the story forward in interesting ways. This might happen as the result of some traumatic event or epiphany.
To tweak an existing Aspect: if the aspect is constantly being exploited by the player then the aspect should be changed. Remember a good aspect has to cause problems for the character occasionally
Other aspects, such as physical aspects, are usually held for the lifetime of the character. For example, suppose Dourli loses a hand in a tragic, yet potentially foreseeable, drunken axe juggling attempt. He gains the Missing Left Hand aspect. Over time this may become much less problematic for him as he adapts to his new condition however he will very likely retain that aspect until his death. Alternatively, the GM can rule that aspect can be diminished and if Dourli manages to get the aspects difficulty down to 5 then it no longer affects him in the usual course of play. That aspect would then become a tag on the character -- just because it no longer effects him in a significant way.
AspectLifecycle AspectEphemeral AspectChronic AspectPermanent Ephemeral Aspect Chronic Aspect Permanent Aspect We distinguish three different Aspect lifetimes: Ephemeral, Chronic and Permanent. Ephemeral aspects last until the aspects difficulty would be reduced below the minimum aspect difficulty. Unless otherwise stated new aspects are assumed to be Ephemeral. Chronic Aspects are active until their difficulty would be reduced below some minimum difficulty, at which point the Aspect becomes dormant for some period of time. Dormant aspects cannot be compelled. Dormant aspects become active again when the GM decides. Permanent Aspects last indefinitely and are always active. The lifetime and effects of all aspects regardless of life-cycle are ultimately determined by the GM, but should be negotiated between players and the GM.
Aspect Advantages
When a player seeks to compel one of their own characters aspects they do so in the hopes of weakening the hold of that aspect upon their character. The idea is that it is far better for a character to decide when their aspect applies to their character than leaving it up to the GM or fellow players to choose a time that may be very inconvenient.
Suppose Dourli is fighting an ogre, and a large amount of treasure is at stake if Dourli can win. The ogre is nearly defeated but Dourli fails his morale check. Dourli's player might try to compel his Gold is my Lodestone aspect to try to get the GM to give Dourli some bonus to his morale check in that fight. He rolls a 5. Well under the aspects difficulty and so is bound by the aspect. The GM decides that Dourli gets a +3 bonus to his morale check as his greed overcomes his sense of self-preservation.
Conflicting Aspects
Sometimes a characters aspects conflict with one another. In such cases someone can compel one aspect to try and gain a bonus on a second aspect check, suppose the GM tries to compel Dourli's Gold is my lodestone aspect to make Dourli sell out one of his companions. The player may counter that Dourli has sworn friendship with the companion while imbibing and that the GM's compel conflicts with his other aspect My word as a dwarf. If Dourli fails the check against My word as a Dwarf then he is bound by that aspect and the GM should grant him a bonus in the check against Gold is my lodestone as Dourli's word is worth more to him than a small amount of gold (though maybe not a large amount of gold).
Vetoing an Aspect
At the end of the day the players character is his own. The GM and other players should not force the player to make his character do something that they do not want their character to do. The player may always veto newly proposed aspects for their character or suggested actions for a compelled aspect. Players should use this veto power only when they really dislike the outcome of a compelled aspect.
Combat ch:combat
Combat Overview
CombatRounds Combat is central to the game and has its own specific set of rules. Combat starts with an optional Initiative, Surprise, or Ambush check, and then a series of Combat Rounds. Every character gets one Turn per Combat Round. You can remember this with the mnemonic Take one turn every time you go round the table.
Initiative, Surprise, and Ambush
Initiative
Turn Order By default, we use Group Initiative where all the members of one group take their turn, then all the members of the next group take their turn, and so on until all the groups involved in the combat have taken their turn. There will typically be one group of PCs and maybe one to three groups of monsters.
The order that groups act in is dependent on context and determined by the GM. In mundane combat encounters the GM can just choose. If the monsters start the fight then perhaps they should have initiative. Otherwise the GM should consider just allowing the PCs to go first. This keeps the game moving and gives the PCs agency. Remember the PCs are supposed to represent heroic individuals who are destined by fate to perform great things. If the check is not going to add interest to the game the GM should not bother with it.
Optionally, a check can be made to determine which order the groups act in. The GM should force these checks when the narrative dictates, to mix-up the combat a little or to punish the PCs for poor strategic decisions. In this case we use one of a number of checks; Initiative, Surprise, and Ambush; to determine the order in which groups act.
Initiative Check An Initiative Check should be made using an ability chosen by the GM, and based on context. Some abilities that could be used to make the initiative check are Perception, Speed, Listen, Notice, and Scout. We use the term Initiative Check to refer to this check irrespective of what underlying ability was used to make the check. Initiative is a group delegate check using one PC's ability checks against the other groups initiative DC. Groups take their turns in order from highest initiative to lowest.
Members within groups can act in any order. The players may choose the order in which they act, within their group, or just take turns acting in clockwise order around the table.
Surprise
sec:surprise Surprise It is possible for some groups within a fight to be unprepared for battle or completely taken off guard. For game purposes we say that a group of characters are Surprised when they are attacked and they are unaware of their attackers at the start of the combat. If both groups or if neither of the groups are unaware then no surprise occurs.
sec:aware What does it mean to be Aware for the purposes of determining surprise? Ultimately, the GM makes the call as to whether one group is aware of the other or not. Typically groups will be aware of one another unless one side has approached the other stealthily. If the GM wishes, the PCs can make an Awareness Check which is a delegate group check using an appropriate ability to see if they are aware of other parties, see Tabletable:{{ doc_name }}-awareness on pagetable:{{ doc_name }}-awareness for suggestions about the appropriate ability check to use. The awareness check can be modified if individuals have the Alert Condition see pagecondition:alert
Dourli, attempts to surprise two gang members in the city by attacking them from behind under the cover of darkness. Dourli is aware of his opponents already, but do the gang members become aware of Dourli? Looking at Tabletable:{{ doc_name }}-awareness we see that the appropriate ability to use is Sneak. Dourli makes a Sneak check against his opponents perception DC. If successful he will surprise the gang members, if he fails to surprise them he probably should still go first in the initiative, since he is a player character and he initiated the attack.
When a group is surprised it gets no actions for the first round of combat, and then must make a morale check. The attackers gain advantage on Std Checks during a Surprise Roll. Additionally, whether the surprise attempt is successful or not the would be surpriser goes first during combat as if they had won initiative.

{% include "docs/tables/initiative.xml" %}
Ambush
Ambush Ambush is special case of surprise roll that occurs when the ambusher has enough time to plan their initial attack well. In order for an ambush to occur the ambushee must move into the ambush zone. The ambushers otherwise may have the time to set traps and snares, prepare actions, cast non-combat spells at the GMs discretion. Players receive a +6 modifier to their surprise when ambushing, and they receive a -6 modifier to their surprise roll when being ambushed. The effects of being ambushed are the same as those for being surprised.
Combat Rounds
Combat rounds represent about ten seconds of time in-game. During a round every member of the combat takes a single Turn.
Actions Standard Action Move Action Minor Action In a characters Turn the character has time to perform a Standard Action, a Move Action and a Minor Action. Actions can be demoted from a Standard Action to a Move or Minor Action, and from a Move Action to a Minor Action. These actions can be performed in any order within a combat round and they are all optional.
There are a few extra complications to combat: Immediate Actions, Reactions, Free Actions, Miscellaneous Actions, and Prepared Actions which we discuss later.
Standard Action
Standard actions are the main combat actions that are used for most physical attacks and many spells. Examples are Sword Strike, Axe Strike and Run actions.
Move Action
Move actions allow the character to move, using the Move, Run, Charge or Flee abilities.
Most combat actions also implicitly include some optional movement. When a character attacks it is understood to involve a movement to close the distance to their opponent. On a grid the distance the character may move is up to the characters movement. Note that there is also a Run action that essentially just allows the character to move twice their normal distance, a Charge action for attacking at a run, and a Flee action. In addition, the characters movement options may be curtailed if they have failed one or more Morale Checks.
Minor Action
A minor action is any operation that can be performed in very short period of time, grabbing an item from your belt, opening a door, picking an item up .
Free Actions
A Free Action is an optional extra action that the character performs in his turn and that does not count against their limit of actions for their round.
Immediate Actions
An Immediate Actions are Free Actions that the characters can perform once, at any time during the round. Examples of Immediate Actions are using Leadership to try and cause a halt to combat to allow negotiation, and Fleeing.
Multi-Turn Actions
Full Turn Action Multi Turn Action Some tasks require longer than a standard action to perform, typically either one or more whole turns. We call these full-turn or multi-turn actions.
A Full Turn Action take a whole turn to complete. That is one standard action, one move action and one minor action. These actions can be performed in any order and they can be started in one turn and finished in another. Multi Turn Actions require some number of full turn actions. For example, a Two-Turn Action requires two standard actions, two move actions and two minor actions to complete.
Collective Action Collective actions allow multiple characters to contribute actions towards a goal. In these cases all characters that contribute must have the appropriate ability. The character that contributes the last required action rolls for the check. Collective actions should have the collective tag.
Interuptable Action Long Actions may or may not be interuptable. If an action is interuptable characters can perform some part of the action, then do something else, and the return to the action and continue performing the action without losing previous progress. If an action is not interuptable then any interuption will cause the action to fail and any progress will be lost. Multi-turn actions should be assume not to be interruptable unless otherwise stated.
Reactions
Reactions Under certain circumstances a character will be able to perform an additional Reaction during someone else's action or when a special triggering event occurs.
Reactions are actions that the GM deems may be performed as a Reaction in a given context, or any abilities specially labelled as such, Shield Block, Sword Parry, Cloak Fighting and Dodge. A character may perform at most one reaction per round. If two or more characters want to react to an action the GM decides the reaction order, possibly using an opposed Speed check.
Miscellaneous Actions
Miscellaneous Actions Miscellaneous actions refer to things that characters do during combat for which no explicit rules exist, reading the runes that close a magic portal, releasing a portcullis, mounting a horse, quaffing a potion, pushing a load of barrels over and so on.
For many miscellaneous actions the GM will just have to make a ruling as to the check required and the type of action; standard, move or minor: as it would infeasible for us to provide rules for the myriad of miscellaneous actions that might occur. We suggest that the GM rule that these are minor actions if they can as it encourages strategic thinking and more variety during combat. You could estimate the time required and work out the actions required as follows.. whole turn is 10 seconds, a standard action is six seconds, a move action is three seconds, and a minor action is one second. Then, if an action will take thirty seconds to perform it will need three whole rounds to complete.
Prepared Actions
If the character knows that a combat is imminent they may declare that they prepare an action. At that point, at the GMs discretion, the action gains a +3 check modifier, a prepared arrow shot triggered when someone enters a room would gain a +3 bonus to succeed.
Boons and Banes
CombatBoons CombatBanes Since combat is such a major part of the game the characters will be rolling Boons and Banes quite often. The standard Boon for martial abilities is double damage. The standard Bane for martial abilities is half damage.
Some suggested boons and banes for use during combat checks can be found in Tables table:{{ doc_name }}-to-hit-boons-and-banes and table:{{ doc_name }}-to-hit-boons_and_banes.

The thugs have returned to the cellars. Dourli and Roslyn have been unable to escape and now a fight looks inevitable. It's still dark and our heroes have managed to hide from the thugs so far. Dourli attacks the thugs from his hidden position attempting to ambush them. The GM notes that the Thugs will be expecting trouble, they are Alert, and so decides the bonus to ambush the thugs is reduced to +3.
Dourli tries to get advantage from the dark tag of the cellars and prepares an attack. The GM agrees and gives the adventurers a +1 arguing that the fact that the thugs were expecting to find Dourli down here would somewhat negate that advantage. Dourli agrees.
As this is a group delegate check the GM chooses Roslyn to check her Sneak versus the thugs Perception DC. If Roslyn succeeds then the Thugs are ambushed, Roslyn and Dourli win initiative and get a free round of attacks, the first attack from Dourli gains a bonus to succeed as a prepared action and the thugs must make a morale check.
Dourli and his ally Roslyn, have been cornered by the local gang leader Fenton One-Eye and two of his thugs. A fight in the cellar of the Inn has been underway for some number of rounds. During the fight a few kegs of whisky have been smashed and there is a shallow pool of whisky on the ground.
One of the thugs attacks Dourli with an Axe Strike I. Dourli defends with a Shield Block 3, since he has rank 3 so he rolls 2D12 with a +3 bonus to his block, the attack has a DC of 13 + 1 for the Axe Strike rank. He needs an 11 or more on his roll to succeed. He roll double fours. That is a failure and also a boon. The GM declares that Dourli takes half damage which for an axe is 3 hit points. That has used Dourlis one reaction for the round.
The second thug tries to stab Dourli with his dagger. Dourli has no reactions left so he has to defend with an Armour save.
Movement and Range
Miniatures vs Theatre of the Mind
Movement Miniatures Theatre of the the mind (TOTM) TOTM (Theatre of the the mind) Combat may either be performed on a table with miniatures using a map with a Grid, or purely narratively using the Theatre of the Mind, TOTM.
If the combat takes place on a grid then the map determines the distances for movement, spell area of effect, missile weapon range etc. On a map a run is simply a double movement, a charge is a movement + d6 extra squares then an attack if the enemy is in range. Fleeing characters move twice their movement rate +d6 extra squares.
Movement is halved over difficult terrain. Difficult terrain includes: muddy ground, rocky ground, and generally any terrain with a lot of debris, brambles etc.
Range Missile weapons and some spells are ranged actions. Up to that range the action is made without any modifiers. If the attack occurs at a distance greater than the range and less than or equal to twice the range then that attack suffers a -3 Long Range modifier. Beyond twice their range the action cannot be taken effectively and will automatically fail.
{% include "docs/tables/combat_modifiers.xml" %}
Cover Cover provides modifiers to checks for most missile weapons and for melee combat. Light Cover afforded by bushes and the like gives a -3 check modifier, Hard cover, such as a half wall, provides a -6 check modifier. Full Cover makes hitting the target impossible. The GM should feel free to choose a check modifier that fits the cover available to the characters.
Zones and Attacks of Opportunity
If characters or monsters move past opponents during combat they may grant an attack of opportunity which is a standard action made as a reaction to the movement. Disengaging from combat and moving away from combat does not grant an attack of opportunity. Allowing characters to move away from combat without granting an attack of opportunity allows more strategic combat and is perhaps a little more realistic.
When playing with TOTM the GM determines whether attacks of opportunity occur. When playing on a grid we need a more precise definition. We start with defining zones. We define a Zone as the one square perimeter around the character, See Figurefigure:zones. Given this definition a character grants an Attack of Opportunity every time the they move from one cell in an opponents zone of control into another cell in any opponents zone of control. The attack of opportunity is granted to the opponent whose cell the character moves to. Do not forget the limit of at most one reaction per character per Turn. In Figurefigure:opportunity_attack, monster A gives attacks of opportunity whenever he moves along the arrows in the diagram.

Flanking sec:flanking
When playing using theatre of the mind, whether or not a character is flanked is determined by role-playing and GM fiat, the GM might require the character makes a check to leap over a table to get into a flanking position.
When playing on a grid a character is said to be Flanked if he is being attacked by two or more opponents from an angle of greater than 90 degrees. Attacks on flanked characters gain a +3 check modifier, see Figurefigure:flanking

Non-Lethal Combat sec:non-lethal-combat CombatNon-Lethal Combat
There are two categories of combat: Lethal and Non-Lethal. In Non-Lethal combat the participants are not actively trying to kill their opponents, but rather trying to subdue them or drive them off.
There is no difference between Lethal and Non-Lethal combat until an opponents stamina reaches zero and someone becomes Bloodied. At that point a decision has to be made as to whether the combat is lethal or non-lethal. If the combat is non-lethal then the bloodied opponent has to willingly withdraw from the combat or make a morale check to convert the combat to a Lethal Combat. So it is possibly for a non-lethal combat to become lethal at some point during the combat. Ultimately the GM decides what type of combat is occurring, but as a guide combat between civilized humanoids, particularly in places with established legal systems and prohibitions against violence, will be assumed to be non-lethal, at least initially. Combat against monsters and uncivilized humanoids should be considered to be lethal be default.
There is a case where, during a non-lethal combat, a character may have lost most of their stamina, and are then hit with a big hit and lose all their remaining health. In such a case the normal rules for reduction of health to zero apply. This will probably result in either the combat becoming lethal, or the opponents running away. Weapons tagged non-lethal reduce the opponents health to one in this case.
Examples of typical non-lethal combat encounters include fights with the local guards, bar-room brawls, fights with gangs of thugs and bandits. There are many reasons to use non-lethal combat: killing people is often a capital crime in human society, there are severe social implications when an individual becomes known as a killer, potentially the players might wish to interrogate an opponent, and bandits might want to make money selling people into slavery.
Healing sec:healing
Refreshes SleepHealing RestHealing Healing Characters may heal by taking a long or a short rest. A Short Rest is a ten minute or more length of time that the characters perform no strenuous activity. At the end of a short rest the characters regain all their Stamina and may refresh one dice pool at their dice pool refresh rate.
A Long Rest is a six hour or more length of time that the characters sleep. At the end of a long rest the characters regain all their Stamina, regain Health at their Health Heal rate, and refresh dice into their dice pools at twice their dice pool refresh rate. Previously unused short rests can be taken at the same time as a long rest.
Morale Checks sec:mettle-checks
Morale Checks Both player characters and monsters may, from time to time, be forced to make a morale check. In order to make life more manageable, the GM and player characters make morale checks differently. The difference between the two checks is that the GM checks for groups of monsters while the PCs check on a per character basis.
Player Character Morale Check
Breaking sec:breaking For player characters Morale Checks are a Mettle Check with a target of 5. When a character fails a morale check another two characters must make a check. Morale checks continue until there are no more fails or everyone has made a morale check. Morale Checks do not count as an action.
Break if: Mettle Pool DC 5
As characters fail morale checks they gain conditions that limit what they can do during combat, see Tabletable:break-difficulties on pagetable:break-difficulties for a list of morale check difficulties and conditions.
For example, looking at the table, the first time a character fails a morale check they gain the Checked condition.
The GM should feel free to modify the break difficulty as he pleases, to reflect being attacked at night, being vastly outnumbered, the horrible visage of the characters opponents, the party being in good spirits etc.
{% include "docs/tables/break_table.xml" %}
Morale checks for players should be made at the GMs discretion. But some suggested times to make morale checks are:
When any party member becomes bloodied,
When the party enters combat against a fear causing opponent,
Whenever the party is surprised or ambushed.
Ultimately, however, it is up to the GM to decide when the players should make a morale check and the GM should feel free to force morale checks sooner or later in the combat to satisfy the narrative imperative.
Monster and NPC Morale Checks
Monsters make Morale Checks as a group. Morale checks for monsters and opposing NPCs should be made when:
After a third of the monsters have died,
After two thirds of the monsters have died,
Whenever the monsters are surprised.
When monsters fail their morale checks they should attempt to break off combat, yield, negotiate or flee, at the GMs discretion.
Fighting in Groups
It is possible to fight in groups. While fighting in a group the front row provides hard cover to the back row. The front row must have at least as many people in it as the back row. To make melee attacks from the back row you must be using a weapon with reach. It is possible for a group to have two front rows, i.e. to be fighting on two fronts, provided that the number of people in each front row is greater than or equal to the number of people in the back row. Furthermore, characters in the back row add a temporary bonus die to their morale checks.

Abilities ch:abilities
This chapter describes abilities available to characters in the game. Abilities Each character has a set of Abilities. Abilities may be used in a variety of ways depending on the ability in question. Some abilities allow the player to perform Actions or Ability Checks while others provide the player with passive advantages.
Abilities are tags and like other tags, they may be used by the player to gain an advantage in an appropriate context.
Abilities have ranks. Some abilities start with an untrained rank, often 0 or -3. Abilities that have an untraind rank can be attempted without training. All characters automatically have all untrained abilities but we do not usually bother to write these down on the character sheet until they reach rank one.
Mastering an Ability AbilityMastery Some abilities have prerequisites. You cannot learn an ability unless you have satisfied the prerequisites for that ability. A prerequisite for all ability ranks is mastery of the previous rank of the ability. That is, in order to gain rank 2 of an ability, rank 1 must first be mastered. In order to master the ability the player must have successfully used the ability three times. If a skill requires another ability rank as a prerequisite that ability rank must also first be mastered. Every time an unmastered ability rank is used the character should mark off the success on their character sheet.
When the character goes up a level they gain promotions in certain classes of abilities up to certain ranks. For example a character might gain the following promotions: Martial3, Hammer4, Transport or Craft6. What this means is that the character can raise the rank of any one ability from the Martial section up to a maximum rank of 3 provided that they have satisfied all of that ability ranks prerequisites. The only time prerequisite requirements are waivered is when the text states that the character gains an ability at a given rank.
All abilities have a type. The type of the ability is mainly used to determine when and if an ability can be used during combat. All abilities have one of the following types: reaction, standard, minor, move, immediate, non-combat, tag. We discuss ability types further in the section on combat.
Default Difficulty Passive Skill DDC (Default Difficulty) SkillDDC SkillPassive SkillDefault Difficulty All abilities have a Default Difficulty, DDC. This is a completely non-binding suggestion to the GM for the difficulty that might be used for checks associated with this skill. Abilities with a DDC of 0 are passive. This means that the the effects of the ability always apply, and that their is no way to successfully make checks with this ability. It follows that there is no way to promote such abilities. Most DDC 0 abilities are reserved for monsters.

Encumbrancesec:encumbrance
Encumbrance CheckEncumbrance Encumbrance is an optional rule. The characters total encumbrance is a difficulty that tests may be made against. For example, characters climbing a mountain may be made to make an Endurance check against their encumbrance or become exhausted. A character leaping from one roof to another who gets a bane in their check may be forced to roll a speed or agility check against their encumbrance or drop some equipment into the streets below. Encumbrance does not simply represent weight, it also represents the unwieldiness of the item; how awkward it is to move while carrying the item.
In order to use encumbrance you should be using the standard character sheets. In the equipment section of the character sheet, marked against the side, are encumbrance values for each class of item (small, medium and large) and values for armour and coin. The total of these values is the characters encumbrance. Note that you do not count items twice ( a shield may be a large object in practice but its encumbrance is counted separately because of the encumbrance values for armour)
If used, it is important that this rule does not become a long-winded exercise in accounting. First roll the check, then calculate the encumbrance (if required). Secondly, don't worry about getting the value exactly right - it will take to long. Just eye-ball it.
